questiontext.text:
Exercise

Consider the vector field \(\underline{F} = -y \underline{i} + x \underline{j} + z\underline{k}\) and the contour around the triangle \((0,0,0), ({@aa@},0,0), ({@aa@},{@aa@},0)\).

Using Stokes' theorem, evaluate either the surface integral or the line integral. [Remember that if evaluated correctly, they will both give the same answer.]

\(I =\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to consider the vector field \(\underline{F} = -y \underline{i} + x \underline{j} + z\underline{k}\) and the contour around the triangle \((0,0,0), ({@aa@},0,0), ({@aa@},{@aa@},0)\) and to use Stokes' theorem to evaluate either the surface integral or the line integral.

Stokes' Theorem tells us that for any vector field \(\underline{F}\) and a contour \(C\) which bounds an area \(S\),

\(\qquad \displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{dS} = \displaystyle\oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\)

You may choose to evaluate this integral either using the surface integral or the line integral side of Stokes' Theorem.

We give the solution for the surface integral method first:

First we find the curl, \({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}\):

\(\begin{align} {\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F} = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} \underline{i} & \underline{j} & \underline{k}\\ \\ \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ \\ -y & x & z \end{array} \right| &= \underline{i} \left| \begin{array}{cc} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ x & z \end{array}\right| - \underline{j} \left| \begin{array}{cc} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial z} \\ -y & z \end{array}\right| + \underline{k} \left| \begin{array}{cc} \dfrac{\partial}{\partial x} & \dfrac{\partial}{\partial y} \\ -y & x \end{array}\right| \\ &= \underline{i} \left(0-0\right) - \underline{j} \left(0-0\right) + \underline{k} \left(1- (-1)\right) \\ &= 2\underline{k} \end{align}\)

Now, since the triangle lies in the \(xy\) plane, our normal vector \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) is \(\mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y \, \underline{k},\) and so our surface integral becomes

\(\begin{align} \qquad\displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{dS} &= \int \int_S 2\underline{k} \cdot \underline{k} \, \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y \\ &= \int \int_S 2\, \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y \\ &= 2 \int \int_A \, \mathrm{d}x \, \mathrm{d}y \\ &= 2 \times \text{Area of Triangle} \end{align}\)

Since our triangle is in the \(xy\) plane, its area is simply \(\dfrac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height}\) and so here since our triangle has base and height of length \({@aa@}\),

\(\qquad \text{Area of Triangle} = \dfrac{1}{2} \times {@aa@} \times {@aa@} = {@area@}\), and so now the surface integral becomes

\(\begin{align} \qquad\displaystyle\int\!\! \displaystyle\int_S ({\underline \nabla} \times \underline{F}) \cdot \underline{dS} &= 2 \times \text{Area of Triangle} \\ &= 2 \times {@area@} \\ &={@ta1@}.\end{align}\)


We now show the line integral solution.

We are aiming to find the line integral \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\) which we do by considering the contribution of each of the \(3\) sides of the triangle separately.

First we find \(\underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\).

We have \(\underline{F} = -y \underline{i} + x \underline{j} + z\underline{k}, \, \) and \(\, \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = \mathrm{d}x \underline{i} + \mathrm{d}y\underline{j} + \mathrm{d}z \underline{k}, \, \) and so

\(\qquad \displaystyle \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = -y \, \mathrm{d}x + x \, \mathrm{d}y + z \, \mathrm{d}z\)

We now consider the contribution of each side to \(\displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r}\):

Side 1: \((0,0,0) \to ({@aa@},0,0)\)

\(y=0, z=0 \implies \mathrm{d}y=0, \mathrm{d}z = 0, \, \text{and} \, x:0 \to {@aa@},\) so we have

\(\qquad \text{Contribution} = \displaystyle \int_0^{@aa@} 0 = 0.\)

Side 2: \(({@aa@},0,0) \to ({@aa@},{@aa@},0)\)

\(x={@aa@}, z=0 \implies \mathrm{d}x=0, \mathrm{d}z = 0, \, \text{and} \, y:0 \to {@aa@},\) so we have

\(\begin{align} \qquad \text{Contribution} &= \int_0^{@aa@} {@aa@} \, \mathrm{d}y \\ &= \left[{@aa@}y\right]_0^{@aa@} \\ &= {@aa^2@}.\end{align}\)

Side 3: \(({@aa@},{@aa@},0)->(0,0,0)\)

\(z=0 \implies \mathrm{d}z = 0,\) and \(x: {@aa@} \to 0, y: {@aa@} \to 0\), and we have the line \(y=x,\) and so \(\mathrm{d}x = \mathrm{d}y\)

\(\begin{align} \qquad \text{Contribution} &= \int_{@aa@}^0 -y \, \mathrm{d}x + \int_{@aa@}^0 x \, \mathrm{d}y \\ &= \int_{@aa@}^0 -x \, \mathrm{d}x + \int_{@aa@}^0 x \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int_{@aa@}^0 \left(-x+x\right) \, \mathrm{d}x \\ &= 0. \end{align}\)

Therefore since our total line integral is the sum of the 3 contributions, we have

\(\qquad \displaystyle \oint_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}r} = 0 + {@ta1@} + 0 = {@ta1@}.\)

This is the same answer as the surface integral, as Stokes' Theorem tells us.
